description: From Middle English concurrent, from Old French concurrent, from Latin concurrēns, present active participle of concurrō (“happen at the same time”), from con- (“with”) + currō (“run”).

adjectives.description: concurrent (comparative more concurrent, superlative most concurrent)

entries.meaning: Happening at the same time; simultaneous.
examples: Such are the changes which science recognizes in the wire itself, as concurrent with the visual changes taking place in the eye.

entries.meaning: Belonging to the same period; contemporary.
Acting in conjunction; agreeing in the same act or opinion; contributing to the same event or effect.
examples: I join with these laws the personal presence of the king's son, as a concurrent cause of this reformation.

entries.meaning: Joint and equal in authority; taking cognizance of similar questions; operating on the same objects.
Running alongside one another on parallel courses; moving together in space.
(computing, of code) Designed to run independently, rather than sequentially, using various mechanisms, such as threads, event loops or time-slicing.
One who, or that which, concurs; a joint or contributory cause.
examples: To all affairs of importance there are three necessary concurrents  […]  time, industry, and faculties.

entries.meaning: One pursuing the same course, or seeking the same objects; hence, a rival; an opponent.
examples: Menander  […]  had no concurrent in his time that came neere vnto him

entries.meaning: One of the supernumerary days of the year over fifty-two complete weeks; so called because they concur with the solar cycle, the course of which they follow.
One who accompanies a sheriff's officer as witness.
